channel.title: DayRep - I need some advice

item.title: DayRep - I need some advice
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:18, topic:41744”]Also if the order in which things are incremented doesn’t matter to you

++i;

is actually faster than

i++;

Just a little useless java knowledge for you ;)[/quote]

Interesting, it is actually true. Although I fail to see why, because the only thing it affects is the order of the load- and increment instruction… (this is in a case where the actual value is needed, and is actually loaded instead of just incrementing.)

A little more “useless” java knowledge, disassemble or decompile this:

int i = 0; i++; ++i; i++; ++i;

It should end this debate

Read full topic

item.title: DayRep - I need some advice
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

When braces have an entire line to themselves my eyes start bleeding.
Also, just since you wanted criticism - method names should start with a lowercase letter. Class names should start with uppercase.

Read full topic

item.title: DayRep - I need some advice
item.dc:creator: @bullzeye95 bullzeye
item.description:
@bullzeye95 wrote:

[code]public class Main{
static long Energy = 7;
static long Hunger = 10;
static long Thirst = 5;

public static void Introduction(){
	System.out.println("Welcome.Hour 1");
	try {
		Thread.sleep(2000);
	} catch (InterruptedException x) {
	System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
}

public static void Morning() {
	System.out.println("Getting out of bed");
	--Energy;
	Hunger++;
	Thirst++;
	try {
		Thread.sleep(10000);
	} catch (InterruptedException x) {
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	System.out.println("Walking to bathroom");
	Hunger++;
	try {
		Thread.sleep(12000);
	} catch (InterruptedException x) {
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	System.out.println("Brushing Teeth + Doing hair");
	try {
		Thread.sleep(120000);
	} catch (InterruptedException x) {
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	System.out.println("Making Breakfast");
	--Energy;
	Hunger++;
	Thirst++;
	System.out.println("Energy Levels Raised");
	try {
		Thread.sleep(50000);
	} catch (InterruptedException x) {
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	System.out.println("Eating breakfast");
	--Energy;
	--Hunger;
	--Thirst;
	try {
		Thread.sleep(300000);
	} catch (InterruptedException x) {
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	Energy++;
	Energy++;
	System.out.println("Morning Finished...Changing Status");
	
}
public static void main(String[] args){
	Introduction();
	Morning();
}

}[/code]
There’s proper indenting.

But I like this form of standards better: [code]public class asdf
{
static long Energy = 7;
static long Hunger = 10;
static long Thirst = 5;

public static void Introduction()
{
	System.out.println("Welcome.Hour 1");
	try 
	{
		Thread.sleep(2000);
	}
	catch (InterruptedException x)
	{
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
}

public static void Morning()
{
	System.out.println("Getting out of bed");
	--Energy;
	Hunger++;
	Thirst++;
	try
	{
		Thread.sleep(10000);
	} 
	catch (InterruptedException x) 
	{
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	System.out.println("Walking to bathroom");
	Hunger++;
	try 
	{
		Thread.sleep(12000);
	} 
	catch (InterruptedException x)
	{
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	System.out.println("Brushing Teeth + Doing hair");
	try 
	{
		Thread.sleep(120000);
	} 
	catch (InterruptedException x)
	{
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	System.out.println("Making Breakfast");
	--Energy;
	Hunger++;
	Thirst++;
	System.out.println("Energy Levels Raised");
	try 
	{
		Thread.sleep(50000);
	}
	catch (InterruptedException x)
	{
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	System.out.println("Eating breakfast");
	--Energy;
	--Hunger;
	--Thirst;
	try 
	{
		Thread.sleep(300000);
	} 
	catch (InterruptedException x)
	{
		System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
	}
	Energy++;
	Energy++;
	System.out.println("Morning Finished...Changing Status");
	
}

public static void main(String[] args)
{
	Introduction();
	Morning();
}

}[/code]

Pretty good for one of your firsts (guessing).

item.title: DayRep - I need some advice
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:5, topic:41744”][quote author=ownagesbot link=topic=58389.msg714641#msg714641 date=1167581725]
also, --Energy; eeeeewwweeee try Energy–; looks nicer
[/quote]

But isn’t the same thing.[/quote]
Actually it doesnt matter, where it matters is in for {…} loops, when you’re gonna use int i(or whatever you declare).
If you do ++i, you’re gonna add to i before performing the loop, and i++ will do the loop and then add to i…

Read full topic

item.title: DayRep - I need some advice
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

well it is IN THAT CONTEXT but

doSummitWith(x++) and doSummitWith(++x) will cause different results (ofc depending on that actual behaviour of the method, it may infact return the same result with both for reasons which are outside of the scope of this post)

item.title: DayRep - I need some advice
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

public class Main{
	static long Energy = 7;
	static long Hunger = 10;
	static long Thirst = 5;


	public static void Introduction(){
		System.out.println("Welcome.Hour 1");
		try {
		        Thread.sleep(2000);
		    	} catch (InterruptedException x) {
		        System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
        }
	}
	public static void Morning() {
		System.out.println("Getting out of bed");
		--Energy;
		Hunger++;
		Thirst++;
		try {
        Thread.sleep(10000);
      		} catch (InterruptedException x) {
        System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
        }
		System.out.println("Walking to bathroom");

		Hunger++;
		try {
		        Thread.sleep(12000);
		      } catch (InterruptedException x) {
		        System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
        }
		System.out.println("Brushing Teeth + Doing hair");

		try {
		        Thread.sleep(120000);
		      } catch (InterruptedException x) {
		        System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
        }
		System.out.println("Making Breakfast");
		--Energy;
		Hunger++;
		Thirst++;
		System.out.println("Energy Levels Raised");
		try {
				Thread.sleep(50000);
		} catch (InterruptedException x) {
				        System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
        }
        System.out.println("Eating breakfast");
        --Energy;
        --Hunger;
        --Thirst;
        try {
				 Thread.sleep(300000);
			} catch (InterruptedException x) {
				        System.out.println("Please Wait..Preforming Tasks...");
        }
		Energy++;
		Energy++;
		System.out.println("Morning Finished...Changing Status");


	}
	public static void main(String[] args){
		Introduction();
		Morning();
	}
}

How can i pretty it up,at the moment it looks a mess…am i breaking any standards and if so, which ones.Also what parts of the codes need replacing?

Its meant to represent the day,hour by hour.Morning - Night.

Read full topic
